module.p:
Generic quantity expressions are quantity expressions which do not involve a specific, numerically expressed, number of things or quantity of substance –
mòran airgid a lot of money
cus feòla too much meat
na h-ùbhlan air fad all of the apples Generic quantity expressions contrast with numeric quantity expressions like còig craobhan five trees, seachdnar chloinne seven children or trì cairtealan de na h-ùbhlan three quarters of the apples.

Perhaps the most common way of forming generic quantity expressions in Gaelic is by using a generic quantity noun like mòran
a lot, barrachd
more, cus
too much.

section.p: Simple generic quantity expressions do not involve any kind of explicit or implicit comparison.

Some simple generic quantity expressions describe large quantities –
mòran gaoil a lot of love
cuid mhath de na taighean a lot of the houses

Others describe small quantities –
beagan bainne a little milk
beagan de na h-uighean a few of the eggs

And others describe neutral quantities –
grunn fhiadh some/several deer

cf. beagan
few, little, modicum, cuid
part, portion, deannan
pinch, puckle, grunn
batch, group, number, iomadh many, several, mòran
lot, many, much, tòrr
heap, mass, an t-uabhas
enormity, great quantity, awful lot.
Comparative generic quantity expressions involve an explicit comparison between two different quantities.

Some comparative generic quantity expressions describe larger quantities –
barrachd airgid (na ...) more money (than ...)
a thrì uiread de na caoraich (’s a ...) three times as many of the sheep (as ...)

Others describe equal quantities –
(a cheart) uiread salainn (’s a ...) (just) as much salt (as ...)
uimhir de na h-ùbhlan (’s a ...) as many of the apples (as ...)

Others describe smaller quantities –
nas lugha airgid (na ...) less money (than ...)
a leth-uiread de na sgeinean (’s a ...) half as many of the knives (as ...)

cf. barrachd
more, predominance, preponderance, nas lugha fewer, less, tuilleadh
more, extra, uimhir / uiread
as/so much/many, quantity, modicum, number.
Implicitly comparative generic quantity expressions involve a merely implicit comparison between different quantities (i.e. measured against an assumed norm).

Some implicitly comparative generic quantity expressions describe excessive quantities (i.e. larger than is necessary) –
cus seòclaid too much chocolate
anabarr eagail an excess of fear

Some others describe sufficient quantities (i.e. as much as is necessary) –
fuil gu leòr enough blood
pailteas de na leabhraichean plenty of the books

Others describe insufficient quantities (i.e. smaller than necessary) –
ro bheag de dh’airgead too little money
ro bheag de na sgoilearan too few of the pupils

cf. anabarr
excess, redundancy, superfluity, cus
glut, too much/many, surfeit, leòr
satiety, sufficiency, enough, plenty, pailteas
abundance, plenty, ro bheag too little, too few.

Superlative generic quantity expressions split a definite quantity into two parts, one larger and one smaller –
a’ chuid as motha den fheòil most of the meat
a’ chuid as lugha de na h-uighean the least of the eggs

Absolute generic quantity expressions involve the whole of a definite quantity –
am fìon air fad / gu lèir all (of) the wine
gin de na buinn any of the coins
càil/sgath den fhìon any of the wine
